Metadata.dc:title: Simply Grievances: Problems With The Library Simplified Android Codebase

Section.title: Orientation
Section.Paragraph: This book represents a comprehensive examination of the issues with the Library Simplified Android client codebases. Specifically, problems are documented for the following codebases:
The Issue Classes section documents the classes of issues seen in all of the codebases, and the Modules section describes specific instances of the issues in each module.
Additionally, this book attempts to identify all caches used in the applications, because caches are typically a source of many problems.

This book is available via an OPDS feed hosted at
https://io7m.github.io/SimplyGrievances/feed.xml.

Section.title: Issue Classes

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: Many issues within the codebases belong to classes of issues rather than being specific, one-off issues. The following sections attempt to describe those classes of issues so that the documentation sections for each module in the codebase can link to the definitions rather than repeating them.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: AUTOVALUE
Subsection.Paragraph: When the codebases were primarily written in Java, the ancient version of Java provided on Android made it very labour intensive to write data classes. A data class is essentially a class used to hold immutable data and has no "behaviour". Writing these by hand in the ancient Java version available on Android means writing lots of methods by hand in order to get pleasant behaviour with regards to comparing values of the classes for equality, hashing values of the class to insert into maps and sets, and printing values of the classes during debugging. The Google AutoValue package provides annotations to generate data classes without having to manually write all of the boilerplate. However, nowadays, the Android codebases have moved to using Kotlin as the primary implementation language, and the language has direct support for writing data classes without needing an external library. The issue here is that the various codebases do still have some old AutoValue-generated Java classes, and haven't migrated to plain Kotlin data classes.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: BUG
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue simply describes known bugs. There will typically be a ticket associated with each instance of this class of issue.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: COMPLEX
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code that is unnecessarily complex. This is often a historical artifact; code may have been written to support use cases that stopped being relevant, but the code was never refactored to remove the now unnecessary parts.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: DEADCODE
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code that can be statically determined to be unused. This class of issue can normally be fixed with trivial refactoring, or even directly by the IDE.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: DESIGN
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code that is fundamentally flawed in its approach. Most code with an issue of this class will need to be completely redesigned and rewritten.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: LIFECYCLE
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code that breaks when subjected to events occurring as part of the obscenely complex and unnecessary Android Lifecycle model. Code with this class of issue could be said to have a design flaw, but the issue is often severe enough that having a separate class of issue to track problems is warranted.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: OBSOLETE
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code that has become unnecessary due to some changes of circumstance.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: STYLE
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes code style issues. These are often trivial issues and can often be corrected mechanically.

Subsection.title: Issue Class: UITHREAD
Subsection.Paragraph: This class of issue describes a subset of lifecycle issues that are specific to a programming approach used throughout the codebase.

The Android UI is single-threaded in the sense that all updates made to UI elements onscreen must be made by code running on the Android UI thread. Code must not block on the UI thread (ie. run or wait for a long period of time without terminating) because this will cause the UI to become unresponsive and may result in the system offering to kill the application. This means that if a long running operation must occur (such as sending a request to a server and waiting for the response), the operation must be scheduled to run on a background thread. Of course, most long-running operations perform actions such as publishing status updates; an operation might periodically publish updates that indicate for how much longer the operation is likely to continue running. Because it's only possible to update a user interface from the UI thread, it's therefore necessary to have some way for a background thread to schedule code that will run on the UI thread at the earliest possible opportunity after a status update is published.

Briefly, the class of issue described here arises from code being scheduled to run on the UI thread that carries a reference to a UI element, but the Android UI system destroys the UI element before the code is allowed to run. The code then runs as scheduled, but crashes the app because the UI element has been invalidated. This is commonly seen where a long-running background operation publishes events to indicate the state of the operation, and code is scheduled to run on the UI thread in response to these events in order to perform operations such as updating onscreen progress bars, and etc.

This, sadly, is a fundamental design flaw in Android (and the entire lifecycle system is also arguably a fundamental design flaw). The above is a common design pattern used in all other UI libraries (such as Swing, JavaFX, GTK, QT, various .NET UI systems, and so on). The main design flaw in this case is that the Android system is allowed to execute code on the UI thread before the user-scheduled UI code can run. Even on other systems that are allowed to invalidate UI elements in this manner, operations on invalid UI elements are simply treated as no-ops and simply do not cause crashes.

The primary method that we've started to use instead is to force events to be delivered onto the UI thread, and code can execute immediately on the UI thread to respond to them, rather than code being scheduled to run later. We've
used the scheduling methods provided by RxAndroid to control event streams in most cases.
It can be assumed that any use of the original API approach will be a source of application crashes and critical bugs.

Section.Footnote: "We" largely meaning Quentin Gliosca. The author of this book can only take credit for causing the original problem due to being under the mistaken impression that the Android UI system wasn't broken.

Section.title: Caches
Section.Paragraph: This section provides a complete listing of all of the caches used in the codebases. A cache in this case is strictly defined to be a mechanism where the application stores some piece of data either in memory or on disk in order to avoid having to execute a more expensive operation to fetch data from the network. It should be understood as a mechanism purely intended to improve performance and responsiveness. A cache is typically a time-limited mechanism where the contents of the cache are expected to be volatile; if the cache doesn't contain an entry for some required piece of data, then the data can simply be fetched and cached, and the application will continue to work without issue. Data is typically automatically evicted from the cache when a time limit expires. This is not the same as code that keeps a copy of some important piece of data in order to be able to operate without access to the original data. A good example of the latter is the audio book player working from a manifest that the application has downloaded and saved at an earlier date - the audio book player would not be able to work without network connectivity if the manifest had not been downloaded and saved. This is not an issue of performance, but an issue of being able to actually do work at all if the network connection is down.

Subsection.title: Book IDs Are Not Unique Enough
Subsection.Paragraph: Book IDs are used to uniquely identify books within the application. Book IDs are produced by hashing the OPDS identifiers of books within a feed. Unfortunately, if two accounts both publish the same book, there will be a book ID collision and the app will be confused as to which account the book belongs.
This could also, theoretically, cause Adobe DRM issues as the wrong credentials will be used for book operations.
Relevant issues: SMA-33.
Issue class: BUG. Severity: Critical.
Proposed solution: Combine the hash of the OPDS identifier and book account ID in order to produce a truly unique value.

Subsection.title: Book Subtask Ordering
Subsection.Paragraph: Subtasks in the book borrowing code do not have any kind of priority ordering. A task is selected for execution if it matches the required media type, and the first matching subtask is used. This means that if there are multiple subtasks that support a given media type, the subtask is selected nondeterministically. Ideally, subtasks would specify some kind of priority ordering to allow overriding another known task.
Issue class: DESIGN. Severity: Minor.
Relevant issues: SMA-153.

Subsection.title: Excessively Single-Threaded Operation
Subsection.Paragraph: The books controller implements all of the code for the main operations the app performs. It executes all of these operations on a single background thread. Operations include:

Because all of these operations happen on a single background thread, the operations cannot be interleaved: If you trigger a book borrowing operation, you cannot perform an account login until the book borrowing and download has completed. This kind of single threaded operation keeps the code simple, but is costly in terms of responsiveness.
Issue class: DESIGN. Severity: Major.

Subsection.Paragraph: The controller code deletes the book database entry for a book when the user instructs it to delete a book. Unfortunately, there's some confusion in the application's UI when this happens, and the user is able to prompt the controller to try to return the book. The return attempt will immediately fail due to the missing database entry.

Relevant issues: SMA-167.

There is an API for forcibly deleting an Adobe device activation, but this will cause the deleted activation to still count towards the limit of six active devices on an account.
Issue class: BUG. Severity: Major.
Relevant issues: SMA-132.

Subsection.title: Grossly Overengineered Bookmark Policy
Subsection.Paragraph: The bookmark policy class is overengineered and unnecessarily complicated. The historical reason for this was that the mechanism for storing bookmarks, parsing bookmarks, and sending and receiving bookmarks to/from the server used to be deeply intertwined and contained within a single method (!) in the R1 reader activity. As part of refactoring, these separate concerns were broken up into their own implementation classes and moved into this module. At the time, due to the complexity of the code, we were unsure as to exactly when and why the application would choose to send or receive bookmarks. The policy was reverse-engineered as much as it could be, and a pure functional implementation of the policy was placed into a class with the intention of refining and expanding the policy at a later date. It turns out that the only policy the application needs is "send all bookmarks as soon as a bookmark is created" and "receive all bookmarks when a book is opened". The complexity in the current policy is entirely unwarranted.
Issue class: COMPLEX. Severity: Major.

Subsection.title: Fragment Backstack Used For Navigation History
Subsection.Paragraph: The current UI uses Android Fragments to construct the catalog interface. The previous version of the UI used Android Activities. In order to have the fewest surprises in terms of implementation, the old Activity-based UI was more or less translated directly to Fragment form. That is, each loaded feed is an instance of a Fragment, and the Android Fragment backstack is used to store the history of feeds through which the user has navigated. Unfortunately, the Android Fragment backstack is fraught with issues and cannot be adequately controlled to give a pleasant user experience.

Additionally, our Fragment instances are stateful, and this state can be invalidated. For example, if the user navigates to a feed in account A, and then navigates to a feed in account B, this will result in a fragment F being placed on the backstack that has a reference to information in account A. If the user then navigates to the settings screen and deletes account A, the Fragment F now contains references to the deleted account A. Any attempt to move F back to the foreground and interact with it in any meaningful way will almost certainly crash the application. The current unpleasant workaround we apply is to simply clear the entire backstack whenever an account is deleted. This is why the user is unceremoniously thrown back to the catalog screen whenever they delete an account.
The proper way to implement this would be to store the navigation history as a navigable data structure in a ViewModel, and use one stateless Fragment instance instead of multiple instances.
Issue class: DESIGN. Severity: Critical.

Issue class: BUG. Severity: Major.
Relevant issues: SMA-203.

Subsection.title: Module Link
Subsection.Paragraph: The module can be found at simplified-analytics-api.

Subsection.title: Activity Listeners
Subsection.Paragraph: The hosting Activity must communicate with Fragments using old-style callback functions. This should be replaced with communcation via a ViewModel (the PDF library predates ViewModels).
Issue class: STYLE. Severity: Minor.

Subsection.title: Library Needs Update
Subsection.Paragraph: The PDF library used is maintained by Minitex, and hasn't been updated for quite a while. It needs updating to use the latest versions of the various Android dependencies.
Issue class: OBSOLETE. Severity: Minor.

Subsection.title: Module Link
Subsection.Paragraph: The module can be found at simplified-viewer-pdf.

Subsection.title: Issues
Subsection.Paragraph: There are no recognised issues in this module.

Subsection.title: Module Link
Subsection.Paragraph: The module can be found at simplified-viewer-spi.

Subsection.title: Version-Specific Maintenance Burden
Subsection.Paragraph: In order to support SAML authentication in an external WebView, custom code had to be written to extract cookies from the WebView's internal database. Multiple versions of this code are required to exist in order to handle all of the different version-specific database formats, and this represents a non-trivial maintenance burden.
Issue class: COMPLEX. Severity: Minor.

Subsection.title: Module Link
Subsection.Paragraph: The module can be found at simplified-webview.
